factoid: Pierre no longer suffered moments of despair, hypochondria, and disgust with life.
The malady that had formerly expressed in acute attacks was driven inward and never left Pierre for a moment.
Pierre asked himself "What for? Why? What is going on in the world?" several times a day.
Pierre began to reflect anew on the meaning of the phenomena of life.
Pierre knew by experience that there were no answers to these questions.
Pierre turned away from those questions.
Pierre took up a book.
Pierre hurried off to the club.
Pierre hurried off to Apollón Nikoláevich’s.
Pierre exchanged gossip of the town.
Pierre thought Hélène has never cared for anything but her own body.
Pierre thought Hélène is one of the stupidest women in the world.
Pierre thought Hélène is regarded by people as the acme of intelligence and refinement.
Pierre thought people pay homage to Hélène.
Pierre thought Napoleon Bonaparte was despised by all as long as he was great.
Pierre thought Napoleon Bonaparte has become a wretched comedian.
Pierre thought Emperor Francis wants to offer Napoleon Bonaparte his daughter in an illegal marriage.
Pierre thought the Spaniards, through the Catholic clergy, offer praise to God for their victory over the French on the fourteenth of June.
Pierre thought the French, through the Catholic clergy, offer praise because on that same fourteenth of June they defeated the Spaniards.
Pierre thought his brother Masons swear by the blood that they are ready to sacrifice everything for their neighbor.
Pierre thought his brother Masons do not give a ruble each to the collections for the poor.
Pierre thought his brother Masons intrigue the Astraea Lodge against the Manna Seekers.
Pierre thought his brother Masons fuss about an authentic Scotch carpet and a charter that nobody needs.
Pierre thought the meaning of the charter is not understood by the man who wrote it.
Pierre thought we all profess the Christian law of forgiveness of injuries and love of our neighbors.
Pierre thought we have built in Moscow forty times forty churches in honor of that law.
Pierre thought yesterday a deserter was knouted to death.
Pierre thought a priest, a minister of that law, gave a soldier a cross to kiss before execution.
Pierre thought the whole of this general deception is accepted by everyone.
Pierre thought the general deception astonished him each time as if it were something new.
Pierre thought he understands the deception and confusion.
Pierre thought he does not know how to tell everyone that he sees it.
Pierre thought he has tried and found that people in the depths of their souls understand it as he does.
Pierre thought people only try not to see it.
Pierre thought it appears that it must be so.
Pierre wondered what is to become of him.
Pierre had the capacity many men, especially Russians, have of seeing and believing in the possibility of goodness and truth.
Pierre had the capacity of seeing the evil and falsehood of life too clearly to be able to take a serious part in it.
Pierre believed every sphere of work was connected with evil and deception.
Pierre believed whatever he tried to be or engaged in was repulsed by evil and falsehood.
Pierre believed every path of activity was blocked by evil and falsehood.
Pierre had to live and find occupation.
Pierre found it too dreadful to be under the burden of these insoluble problems.
Pierre abandoned himself to any distraction to forget the problems.
Pierre frequented every kind of society.
Pierre drank much.
Pierre bought pictures.
Pierre engaged in building.
Pierre read above all.
Pierre read and read everything that came to hand.
Pierre picked up a book and began to read when he came home.
Pierre passed from reading to sleeping.
Pierre passed from sleeping to gossip in drawing rooms of the club.
Pierre passed from gossip to carousals and women.
Pierre passed from carousals back to gossip, reading, and wine.
Drinking became more and more a physical and moral necessity for Pierre.
Doctors warned Pierre that with his corpulence wine was dangerous for him.
Pierre drank a great deal of wine.
Pierre was at ease when he poured several glasses of wine mechanically into his large mouth.
Pierre felt a pleasant warmth in his body after drinking wine.
Pierre felt amiability toward all his fellows after drinking wine.
Pierre felt readiness to respond superficially to every idea without probing it deeply after drinking wine.
After emptying a bottle or two, Pierre felt dimly that the tangled skein of life was not as dreadful as he had thought.
Pierre was always conscious of some aspect of the skein of life.
Pierre had a buzzing in his head after dinner or supper and chatted or listened to conversation or read.
Under the influence of wine, Pierre said to himself: "It doesn't matter. I'll get it unraveled. I have a solution ready, but have no time now—I'll think it all out later on!".
The later on never came.
